Mandates that all Alabamans wear a mask when in an indoor space open to the general public, a vehicle operated by a transportation service, or an outdoor public space where ten or more people are gathered. Exceptions for people under six or who are medically unable to wear a mask. Coded as Mandate2 because although masks are required in both indoor and outdoor spaces, the parameters on the spaces involved are relatively narrow (for instance, masks are only required in outdoor spaces if ten or more people are present). Extended to 20200831 https://governor.alabama.gov/assets/2020/07/2020-07-29-15th-Supplemental-SOE-COVID-19.pdf Extended to 20201002 https://governor.alabama.gov/newsroom/2020/08/seventeenth-supplemental-state-of-emergency-coronavirus-covid-19/

First issuance is schools staying closed until March 30 (i.e., extending spring break), issued 20200313 https://www.alaskapublic.org/2020/03/13/governor-says-all-k-12-students-in-alaska-to-attend-no-contact-school-until-march-30/ ...all public and private schools closed on 20200320 https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/03202020-SOA-COVID-19-Health-Mandate-008.pdf, extended to end of the school year. Alaska Smart Start 2020 framework released on 20200520 and updated document on 20200727. Framework details how school districts can choose to reopen and provides guidance for those determined as low, medium and high risk environments https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf.  Grants local districts the authority to determine whether to operate in-person, online, or a hybrid contingent on the school district's assessment of the risk level, ending the SchoolClose: https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf

All libraries, archives, and museums to be closed March 17-31. Extensions and expansions, including one on 20200409, removed expiry date. 20200422 executive order began easing of restrictions conditional on meeting extensive health safety guidelines https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
Limited operations required: bars and breweries trucks, self-service dining. Easing as part of Phase II on 20200508. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf
Limited operations required: restaurants, food trucks, self-service dining. Easing began on 20200424 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
(quote) no gatherings of more than 10 people may take place (quote). Mandated for Fairbanks North Star Borough and Kethikan Gateway Borough only. No expiry provided.

Only applicable to Anchorage. Enacted at 10 pm on 20200322, was effectively replaced by the statewide StayAtHome order on 20200328. Expired on 20200401 since order was through 1159pm https://www.muni.org/departments/mayor/pressreleases/documents/eo-03.pdf

Mandates 14 day quarantine for all people arriving in Alaska from anywhere else. PolicyCodingNotes: In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. The 20200424 order allows non-essential businesses to re-open to in-person services conditional on meeting health and safety mandates https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. The 20200424 order indicates the following (quote) Individuals are no longer required to stay home as previously required (quote), effectively ending the order. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Travel between communities banned unless for critical personal or infastructure needs. A 20200409 update to health order removed initial expiry. The 20200424 order eased intra-state restrictions https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry as 20200409 update removed expiry. Added 20200424 as DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Highly recommended for all Alaskans: wear a cloth face covering in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain. On 20200424, strengthened phrasing, (quote) In all gatherings that include multiple households, cloth face coverings should be worn by all participants (quote): https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

Requires patrons to wear cloth face coverings when at retail businesses, personal care services (except for being able to be removed for a short time during necessary services - otherwise, must be worn at all other times including when entering and exiting the shop). On pdf page 30 of the mandate, also includes the following under indoor gatherings: (quote) At gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, when possible. (quote) Coding to a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to very limited settings. Health Mandate 16 is no longer in effect as on 20200522 with Alaska going to Phase 3: https://gov.alaska.gov/newsroom/2020/05/19/governor-announces-phase-three-of-reopen-alaska-responsibly-plan/

(quote) Any family member who is ill with COVID-19 must be immediately isolated in their home or permitted place of residence of isolation (quote). Details how people who exhibit symptoms of COVID-19 must not leave their dwelling within 72 hours of their last fever, and then individuals who have known exposure to indivduals who tested positive for COVID-19 shall self-quarantine for 14 days following the last exposure. Also refers to CDC guidelines https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fhcp%2Fguidance-prevent-spread.html

No gathering larger than 20 people is allowed, which includes the minimum number of necessary personnel to facilitate the event, or 25 percent maximum occupancy (whichever is smaller). Gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, whenver possible. Also applies to religious gatherings.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Part II of recovery phase includes prohibition on gatherings of 50 or more. Ended 20200522, as as gathering limits became a recommendation https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-Alaskas-Plan-Forward-Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEased and added DateEnded of 20200522, updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) the following workplace policy is being implemented by the Office of the Governor: All employees, contractors, and visitors to State of Alaska facilities must wear a facemask if social distancing of at least six feet or more between individuals cannot be maintained. PolicyCodingNotes: Travelers from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and New Orleans, Lousiana and all international locations are recommended to self-quarantine for 14 days. Ended on 20200615 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_business_limitations_phase_II.pdf

Everyone should wear a face covering, or mask, in public. Recommendation issued by Department of Health. Recommendation extended and made more specific on 20200619. On 20200703, This EO allows local ordinances making masks mandatory in conjunction with discussion with the governors office..

(quote) A 14-day self-quarantine is required for travelers entering Arkansas who have visited an international location or an area of high community transmission in the United States in the previous 14 days. (quote) Policy ended on 20200615, no more quarantine requirement for travellers both domestic and international.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateEnded to 20200615 and updated policynotes to include when policy ended

PolicyCodingNotes: Eased gathering restriction to no numerical value. All gatherings (no matter the number) should adhere to rules from the dept of health. All gatherings now subject to rules from Dept of Health, no numerical restriction in place.

Requires (quote) every person in Arkansas to wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing. (quote) Exemptions are for children younger than 10, individuals whose medical condition or disability prevent them from wearing a face covering, exercisng, at worship or religious services. Technically does not apply to counties where no newly identified cases for 28 straight days, but without further details on these counties, we are currently coding as statewide. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor environments and outdoor settings unless physical distancing is practiced. Extended to 20201015 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-45.pdf

Bars, wineries, breweries, and pubs should be closed, except for venues that are currently authorized to provide off-sale beer and wine to be consumed off premises

(quote) Gyms, health clubs, and theaters should be closed (quote). Coded as a recommendation from the CDPH
Limited operations recommended (drive-through, take-out, delivery): restaurants. No onsite consumption should not occur.

PolicyCodingNotes: Bars, wineries, breweries, and pubs must be closed unless authoritized for take-away sales. Began easing on 20200612, allowing counties that completed advanced Phase 2 attestation to re-open bars, wineries, and tasting rooms. On 20200713, CA moved to re-close all bars and restaurants, constituting a state-wide reexpansion. Starting on 20200831, Tier 3 counties can reopen for outdoor services and Tier 4 counties can reopen for outdoor services and up to 50 pct indoor: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/COVID19CountyMonitoringOverview.aspx

Gathering restriction without numerical limits instituted with the enactment of the stay-at-home order. Governor does not set numerical ;limits at the state-level, defers to counties to do this. State-level restriction on gatherings continued on 20200912: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/Guidance-for-the-Prevention-of-COVID-19-Transmission-for-Gatherings.aspx

Easing of certain businesses under Stage 2 Reopening: retail (curbside and pick-up), manufacturing, offices, select services (carwash, pet grooming, landscape gardening), outdoor museums and open gallery places. https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf

First instance of full other business close accompanies NEBusinessClose. Starting on 20200526, counties with advanced Stage 2 attestation could re-open hair salons and barbershops. Among counties that have completed advanced Stage 2 attestation, more easing of business closure restrictions formally began on 20200612: destination retail, cardrooms and similar betting facilities, family entertainment centers and movie theaters, fitness facilities, museums, galleries, zoos, and acquariums, professional sports without live audiences, music TV and film production.

Limited operations required (take-out, delivery) for restaurants and like establishments. No in-person services. Easing began with Phase 2 attestation processes: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx.

Issued/enacted immediatedly. Note shelter-in-place and stay-at-home are being treated as equivalent at present. Considered an eased mandate starting 20200508: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf Further easing of the mandate occurred starting 20200831: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/8-28-20_Order-Plan-Reducing-COVID19-Adjusting-Permitted-Sectors-Signed.pdf

Provides guidance around using face coverings - defaults to county policies, some of which are mandates (documentation of this may occur in the future) - but indicates that individuals should wear coverings if they feel comfortable doing so if counties do not have formal recommendations or mandates. Treating as a statewide recommendation

(quote) People in California must wear face coverings when they are in high-risk situations listed below (quote), inside of, or in line to enter, any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding in public transportation or in a tax, private vehicle, or ride-sharing vehicle, workplace, operating transportation where others are present, and in outdoor public spaces where maintaining 6 ft or more distance is not feasible. Expands previous recommendation to a mandate.

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close wineries and tasting rooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Bars must close all operations, even if they operate outdoors. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx Since July 1, more counties have been added, and removed, from the County Monitoring List and thus their restrictions have increased and been eased accordingly

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close movie theaters, family entertainment centers (e.g., bowling alleys, miniature golf, batting cages and arcades), zoos, museums, cardrooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx Since July 1, more counties have been added, and removed, from the County Monitoring List and thus their restrictions have increased and been eased accordingly

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close restaurants unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx Since July 1, more counties have been added, and removed, from the County Monitoring List and thus their restrictions have increased and been eased accordingly

PolicyCodingNotes: Counties certified to meet Protect Our Neighbors attestation can have gathering activities up to 500 people while maintaining social distancing. Extended to 20200820 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20142%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors%20-%20Alcohol.pdf On 20200723, amended EO extended this policy to 20200822: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20144%20Amending%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf Extended to 20200906 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20154%20Protect%20Our%20Neighbors.pdf Extended to 20201005 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20178-Protect%20Our%20Neighbors.pdf

Issues statewide mask order, requiring people in Colorado who are 11 years and older to wear a covering over their noses and mouths when entering or moving within any public indoor space, or while using or waiting to use public (buses, light-rail) or non-personal (taxis, car services, ride-shares) transportation services. Exemptions for individuals who cannot wear masks or face coverings due to medical conditions or disabilities, and does not require masks in outdoor spaces (though encourages such use). Includes worship services. In effect at midnight on 20200716, so coded to 20200717. Coded as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it covers broadly covers indoor settings and explicitly does not require mask use in outdoor settings. Extended to 20200913 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20164%20Non%20Medical%20Face%20Covering.pdf Extended to 20201012 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20190%20Nonmedical%20Face%20Coverings.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Any person in a public place in Connecticut who is unable to or does not maintain a safe social distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face-covering. Also must use mask or face covering in transportation services. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as this applies to all public places, and does not distinguish between indoor or outdoor settings (and thus is applicable in all public places). Extended for 6 months on 20200814, so coding to 20210212 (182 days later) - this extension also includes a small expansion, requiring documentation for medical exemptions: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7NNN.pdf

Eased gathering restriction of 5 to 10 people for indoor settings. (quote) indoor social and recreational gatherings as described in Executive Order No. 7D, Section 1 are permitted for up to and including ten (10) people (quote). . However, religious gatherings are exempt quote) effective immediately, the 49-person limit on religious, spiritual and worship gatherings is raised for indoor gatherings to 25 percent of capacity of the indoor space or a maximum of 100 people, whichever is smaller, and to 150 people for outdoor gatherings (quote)

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions for both indoor and outdoor gatherings. Restrictions are (quote) amended to permit social and recreational gatherings pursuant to DECD Rules for Gatherings and Venues and Sector Rules for Outdoor Events (quote), and thus permit up to 25 people for indoor private gatherings and 100 for outdoor private gatherings (e.g., weddings, reunions, parties). No limits on religious gatherings provided.

Travelers entering Connecticut from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10 pct test positivity rate over a seven-day rolling average, shall self-quarantine for a period of 14 days. On 20200630, Expands states included in the travel quarantine requirement, adding eight states to the list. The total list is as follows: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah: https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/06-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-June-30  On 20200707, Expands states included in the travel quarantine requirement, adding Delaware, Kansas, and Oklahoma: https://portal.ct.gov/Office-of-the-Governor/News/Press-Releases/2020/06-2020/Governor-Lamont-Coronavirus-Update-June-30  As of 20200714, removes Delaware and adds Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, and Wisconsin now on the travel quarantine list: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Travel-In-or-Out-of-CT On 20200724, the policy removed Ninth modification to state of emergency declaration.  Extended to 20200601 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/second-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/ Eased to exclude religious gatherings on 20200520 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/eighteenth-state-of-emergency/.

Mandatory face coverings, (quote) All individuals must wear a face covering, except where doing so would inhibit that individuals health or where the individual is under two years of age (quote). Applies to riding public transportation or in other types of vehicles (taxis, private car service, ride sharing), customer of any businesses (including, but not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, supermarkets, laundromats, and restaurants, both inside the business and when waiting in line outside), when obstaining services from a healthcare provider, when they are in an outdoor public area if maintaining social distancing is not possible, and when they are in any public area and are feeling sick, coughing, or sneezing. Coded as a PublicMaskLevel Mandate3 as it requires mask wearing in any business and outdoor public spaces. Extension on 20200805 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/fifth-extension-declaration-of-a-state-of-emergency/ Extension on 20200903 https://governor.delaware.gov/health-soe/twenty-seventh-modification-state-of-emergency-declaration/

Eighteenth modification of state emergency includes and easing restrictions for houses of worship. These places (quote) may conduct in-person services or activities at which attendance may reach a maximum of 30 pct of stated fire occupancy requirements (quote).

All persons are prohibited from gathering indoors or in partially enclosed spaces in groups of ten (10) or more people until after June 15, 2020. Gatherings up to 250 are permitted in unenclosed outdoor spaces, or tents if protocols are followed, for outdoor events. Lists detailed requirements for hosting an event up to 250 people (i.e., following distancing guidelines, must wear face coverings)

Recommends vulnerable individuals to continue staying home. (quote) All individuals living in Washington, DC, are order to stay at their place of residence, except as specified in this order (quote)

People using ride share programs, taxis, or other private transportation vehicles are required to wear masks or face coverings. Also recommends wearing masks on public transportation. Coded as Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is a mandate one specific arena for the public (i.e., ride-share, taxis, and private transportation). On 20200513, expands mandate to cover all types of transportation, but still coded to Mandate1 for only applying to a specific sector: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayors-Order-2020-066-Extensions-of-Public-Emergency-and-Public-Health.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200609, removed DateEased, added Mandate1 to PublicMaskLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) DOH guidance relating to masks must be followed (quote), thus making the following guidelines for mask use mandatory: masks and face coverings for the general public, indicating that the general public should wear a cloth face covering when taking care of people with suspected or confirmed COVID-19, entering a healthcare providers office, entering a public setting where social distancing is difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery store pharmacy), or if you are having respiratory symptoms. Also expands the mask mandate for wearing face coverings on transportation. Coded as Mandate2. because it does not expressly require masks or facial coverings across all public settings (indoor and outdoor), and due to its less than direct mandate approach (i.e., must follow guidance from DOH) versus expressly mandating masks. On 20200622, eased to a recommendation with Phase 2: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

Establishes eased gathering rule for religious groups. (quote) Places of worship may operate with expanded capacity limits. In no event shall attendance at any service exceed fifty percent (50%) of the capacity of the facility or one hundred (100) persons, whichever is fewer (quote). Also eases the overall restriction for nonreligious gatherings from 10 to 50 - both indoor and outdoor. (quote) The prohibition on large gatherings of more than ten (10) individuals, in force since March 24, 2020 (Mayors Order 2020-053), is repealed and replaced by a prohibition on mass gatherings of over fifty (50) persons (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases mask policy to a recommendation for the broader public, while still requiring masks to be worn by customers upon entering or waiting in line to enter essential businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to limited settings.

Mask requirement applies whether in an indoor space, such as the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives, or businesses or other establishments open to the public, or public transportation, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. Exemptions include for individuals under the age of 2 yeras old, due to medical conditions or disabilities, etc. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings.

Quarantine order for entry into DC (quote) All residents and persons traveling to or from high-risk areas within the prior fourteen (14) days for non-essential travel must self-quarantine for fourteen (14) days following their return or arrival to the District (quote). Maryland and Virginia are exempt from high risk area label. As of 20200727, these states are as follows (and will be updated on 20200810): Arkansas, Arizona, Alabama, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-list-high-risk-states As of 20200810 the list of states is as follows: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states On 20200824 states that were added to the updated list include: Delaware, Hawaii, and South Dakota and states that were removed include Montana and New Mexico https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-8-24-2020. Requires wearing individuals 8 years old and older to wear a mask or other face covering in public indoor spaces (inclusive of commercial entities), public transportation and vehicle services (inclusive of taxis and ride shares), and outdoor public spaces when social distancing from others is not possible. Such requirements will also be applicable to students, faculty, staff, etc. in schools in 3rd grade and up. Makes exemptions for private offices, private workspaces, and meetings where 6 ft of social distancing can be achieved, as well as children under the age of 2 years, individuals with with a medical condition or disability preventing the wearing of a face covering, when engaging in sports, attending/engaged in a religious service where social distancing is occuring of at least 6 ft. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal EO was signed on 20200724, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722).

PolicyCodingNotes: Continues gathering restriction of more than 10 on social, community, recreational, leisure, and sporting gatherings and events. Expressly excludes spiritual and religious gatherings under this section, though says wedding receptions of more than 10 people are considered social gatherings that are prohibited (more than 10 can attend the ceremony)

No longer prohibits large gatherings of any kind, but social distancing must be in place. Clarifies that the following are all permitted: social, community, recreational, leisure, or sporting gathering or event, including but not limited to a parade, festival, farmers market, auction, convention, or fundraiser, Non school sporting and recreational events, Spiritual and religious gatherings. No numerical rule in place.

Closes bars in Black Hawk, Dallas, Johnson, Linn, Polk and Story Counties only. All bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs, and other establishments that sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on their premises shall be closed to the general public except for carry-out, delivery or drive-through. On 20200915,  Black Hawk, Dallas, Linn, and Polk Counties are no longer under this policy, easing it overall: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.09.15.pdf
Strongly encourages Iowans two years and older to wear a mask when in public settings, especially when it is not possible to remain six feet away from others.

Restaurants in Black Hawk, Dallas, Johnson, Linn, Polk and Story Counties may only reopen or remain open if they comply with the following requirements. If the establishment serves alcohol they must also prepare and serve food, and the sale of alcohol must not be more than half of thee monthly revenue. The establishment must ensure 6 feet of social distance between groups. Alcohol may only be served from 6am to 10pm. On 20200915,  Black Hawk, Dallas, Linn, and Polk Counties are no longer under this policy, easing it overall: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.09.15.pdf
Extended to at least 20201016: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/EO-20-64-Executed.pdf
Funerals, religious gatherings, governments exemptions. Otherwise, gathering restrictions on no more than 50 people

Closing all public and private K-12 schools. Eases restrictions starting on 20200518, allowing for a maximum of 10 people to gather for in-person services in schools. Ended on 2020526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

People traveling from places with widespread community transmission must quarantine for 14 days, no expiry provided. Ended on 20200526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf and reexpanded on 20200608 https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-recommends-communities-move-into-phase-3-of-ad-astra-plan/

Establishment of the Kansas Essential Functional Framework (KEFF) by default closed at least some non-essential businesses by their exclusion from this list. Ended on 20200526 https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

Only takeout and delivery services are declared as essential functions under Executive Order 20-16, KEFF 400.6.b.. (quote) all individuals within the state of Kansas are directed to stay in their homes or residences unless performing an essential activity (quote). Stay at home ended for all individuals, recommendation now occurring for high-risk individuals

Gathering restriction on 10 person gatherings is expanded to include religious gatherings on 20200407 with an enact date of 20200408, legislature struck down, case heard by Supreme Court, which decides in favor of governors order: inclusion of religious gatherings in restriction allowed. (quote) the number of people conducting the service may exceed ten (quote) - see Sec. 1C. Eased on 20200522 with Ad Astra Phase 2: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/EO-20-34-Implementing-Phase-2-Executed.pdf

High risk individuals are adivsed to continue to stay at home except when conducting essential functions (high risk being indiviudals with underlying medical conditions or are otherwise immunocompromised)  Ended on 20200526 with Ad Astra ending https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf

Mass gatherings of no more than 15 individuals allowed. Phase 2 of Ad Astra now formally implemented, but is now different from what had been planned. Ended on 20200526 when Ad Astra became a guideline for counties: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2020-05-26-Proclamation.pdf
Recommends not to have gatherings of over 45 people  https://governor.kansas.gov/governor-laura-kelly-recommends-communities-move-into-phase-3-of-ad-astra-plan/

PolicyCodingNotes: Any person in Kansas shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or other face covering when they are in the following: inside or in line to enter any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding on public transportation or other modes of transportation (taxi, private car service, ride-sharing), outdoors in public spaces and unable to maintain a 6 ft distance between individuals. Exceptions involve individuals with medical conditions, mental health conditions, or disabilities that prevent wearing a mask, children under 5 (especially 2 and younger), people who are deaf or are hard of hearing, when seated at a restaurant, more listed in section 3. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use in across indoor and outdoor settings.
On 3/11/2020: Advised that all community gatherings should be cancelled or postponed. Not coded as restriction at present.

Bars must limit in-person services indoors to 50 pct of capacity: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf

(quote) https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf

All in-person retail businesses that aren't life-sustaining to close at 8:00 pm on 20200323. These include entertainment, sporting goods, clothing, shoe, jewelry and furniture stores, florists, bookstores and auto dealers

(quote) Only life-sustaining businesses may remain open (quote). Easing to begin on May 11 of manufacturing, professional services, pet grooming https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=148

No formal stay-at-home order issued yet, coding as 0 as Mandate for now. This Order should be construed broadly to prohibit in-person work that is not necessary to protect or sustain life. Beshear said Kentucky is adopting on a voluntary basis the new guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommending that people wear cloth masks in some situations. Gov. Beshear also stressed that wearing a cloth mask is a measure to be added to social distancing, not to replace it

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) People in Kentucky must cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when they are in the following situations that represent a high risk of COVID-19 transmision (quote). Lists while inside or waiting in line to enter many businesses or indoor public space where it is difficult to physical distance, while waiting for or riding on public transportation or other vehicles (eg taxi, private car service, ride sharing), and in outdoor public spaces where physical distancing of 6 ft is not possible. Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions), among others. In effect for 30 days after 5 pm on 20200710. PolicyCodingNotes: The advisory recommends a 14-day self-quarantine for travelers who went to any of eight states reporting positive testing rate equal to or greater than 15 percent-for COVID-19 testing. The advisory also includes one state quickly approaching a positive testing rate of 15 percent and one U.S. Territory. They include Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Nevada, South Carolina and Texas, Mississippi and Puerto Rico. On 20200824 removes Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Florida from the quarantine advisory and adds South Carolina https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=328.   As of 20200923, they include South Dakota, Kansas, Iowa and Wisconsin, Idaho. The list appears to be updated daily but not reported consistently via any government sources, and thus they cannot be tracked in an ongoing manner.https://govstatus.egov.com/kycovid19
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated list of states in PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Visitors are instructed not to travel to Maine if they are displaying symptoms of COVID-19, and are advised not to travel to Maine if they are traveling from cities and regions identified as COVID-19 hotspots, including the cities of Detroit, Chicago, New York. Residents of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut should refrain from travel in compliance with CDC travel guidance. Extended to 20200601 on 20200429 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

Individuals must wear cloth face coverings in public settings where other physical distancing measures are difficult to maintain. Public settings are defined as indoor spaces accessible to the public (e.g., grocery stores, retail stroes, retail stores, pharmacies, healthcare facilities), outdoor spaces (e.g., playgrounds, busy parking lots, and other areas such as lines for take-out service where the public typically gathers in a small area), public transportation (eg, taxi, ride-sharing, ferry, bus, train, and any semi-enclosed transit stop or waiting area). Exemptions are for children under the age of 2, anyone who cannot wear a mask due to a condition, medical or other types of physical or mental conditions. Coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires mask use in both indoor and outdoor settings. On 20200531, clarified that masks were required for large gatherings, including those outside: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Further%20Implement%20the%20Restarting%20Plan.pdf

The stay-at-home mandate is (quote) eased to the extent that people may access the increased business and personal activities that are being reopened. Until further notice, persons who are over age 60 or who have a medically compromised condition are strongly urged to limit their movement and activities that expose them to persons other than immediate household members, and to avoid large gatherings, especially those occurring indoors or in otherwise confined settings (quote)
Gathering restriction on more than 50 people. Eased on 20200801: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO%206%20-%20fy20-21.pdf

Eases outdoor gathering restrictions. (quote) The limit on the number of persons for outdoor gatherings is 5 people per 1,000 sq. ft of occupiable outdoor space or not more than 100 persons whichever is less. The limit on the number of persons for indoor gatherings remains at 50 persons as set forth in Executive Order 55 FY 19/20.(quote)

People arriving in MA are (quote) instructed (quote) to self quarantine for 14 days, no expiry date provided. Gov language and press release references CDC and dept of state guidance. On 20200724, following policy was issued: All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/doc/july-24-2020-travel-order-pdf/download Effective Friday, August 7, Rhode Island is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 14, Hawaii  is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont.  https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 29, Colorado, Delaware, Pennsylavnia and West Virginia are added to the list of lower-risk states. All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Vermont and West Virginia https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective September 5, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming are added to the list of lower-risk states https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order  Effective September 12, 2020 Delaware, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia were removed from the list of lower-risk states, and New Mexico was added to the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, Washington, and Wyoming. https://boston.cbslocal.com/2020/09/11/massachusetts-removes-delaware-pennsylvania-west-virginia-lower-risk/ Effective September 19, 2020 Wyoming was removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, and Washington.

(quote) Effective Wednesday, May 6, 2020, any person over age two who is in a place open to the public in the Commonwealth, whether indoor or outdoor, and is unable to or does not maintain a distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering, except where a person is unable to wear a mask or face covering due to a medical condition or the person is otherwise exempted by Department of Public Health guidance. (quote). Also emphasizes the requirement for persons to wear masks or face coverings at all times when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, and other retail stores, as well as all transportation services. Coded as Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or the equivalent in indoor and outdoor public areas.

For outdoor gatherings, no more than 100 people or 25 pct of capacity. Applicable to all locations except for Boston on 20200706, which be in effect on 20200713. Except in businesses that are reopened under Phase III, no indoor gatherings of more than 25 allowed, easing previous gathering restrictions. No more than 8 people per 1000 sq ft, or 25 in any enclosed space. Applicable to all locations except for Boston on 20200706, which be in effect on 20200713

Effective 1201 on Aug 11, in effect until end of emergency.

Any individual who leaves their home or place of residence must wear a face covering over their nose and mouth when in any indoor public space, when outdoors and unable to consistently maintain a distance of six feet or more from individuals who are not members of their household, and when waiting for or riding on public transportation, while in a taxi or ridesharing vehicle, or when using a private car service as a means of hired transportation. Makes exemptions for children under 5 years old, individuals who cannot medically tolerate a face covering, during exercise, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or face coverings in any indoor or outdoor space when unable to maintain physical distancing in public. On 20200717, order is extended and clarifies that this mandate is not required when at a polling place for purposes for voting, as well as when when engaging in religious worship while at a house of religious worship (though strongly encouraged to wear face coverings during religious services, per CDC): https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/07/17/file_attachments/1498115/EO%202020-153%20Emerg%20order%20-%20Masks%20-%20re-issue.pdf Starting on 20200811, all staff, visitors, and children over 2 required to wear face masks in childcare facilities https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/08/06/file_attachments/1512889/EO%202020-164%20Emerg%20order%20-%20masks%20and%20camps.pdf

Minnesotans are required to wear a face covering (quote) in an indoor business or public indoor space, including when waiting outdoors to enter an indoor business or public indoor space, and when riding on public transportation, in a taxi, in a ride-sharing vehicle, or in a vehicle that is being used for business purposes (quote). Strongly encourages the use of face coverings in indoor and outdoor social gatherings, when riding in a private vehicle with others who are not in the same household, when participating in sporting events, and when outdoors in a public business or outdoor space where physical distancing is not possible. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it covers multiple sectors but is limited to indoors. Coded to going into effect on 20200725.

PolicyCodingNotes: Social gatherings shall be limited to a maximum of 10 participants indoors and 20 participants outdoors (when social distancing not happening) for the following counties: Claiborne, De Soto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rankin, Sunflower, Washington, Wayne. On 20200720, added Bolivar, Covington, Forrest, Humphreys, Panola, Sharkey, Simpson, Tallahatchie, Tate and Walthall to this restriction: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1509.pdf

Customers shall wear a face covering, covering nose and mouth, inside retail businesses, as well as indoor and outdoors (when unable to maintain a minimum of 6 ft of separation from other individuals), when attending public events (including but not limited to events in outdoor sports complexes, multi-field complexes, and areas). Applicable to the following counties: Claiborne, De Soto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rankin, Sunflower, Washington, Wayne. Coded as a Mandate2 as it is applicable to many indoor settings as well as some outdoor settings. Starting on 20200720, additional counties are added to this list: Bolivar, Covington, Forrest, Humphreys, Panola, Sharkey, Simpson, Tallahatchie, Tate and Walthall, and extends to 20200803: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1509.pdf Starting on 20200725, additional counties are on this mandate: Calhoun, Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1512.pdf Starting on 20200803, additional counties are on this mandate (also extended to 20200817): https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1515.pdf

All indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals statewide. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms. Counties had been gradually added to a 10 person gathering restriction since 20200710.
All persons residing in Mississippi must immediately home-isolate on first knowledge of infection, and must remain in the home or appropriate residential location for 14 days from onset of illness.

The start of the 2020-21 academic year for public schools in Bolivar, Coahoma, Forrest, George, Hinds, Panola, Sunflower, and Washington Counties for grades 7 thorugh 12 shall be delayed until Monday August 17 2020.

Every person in Mississippi shall wear a face covering while inside a business, school, or other building or space open to the public, or when in an outdoor public space whenever it is not possible to maintain a minimum of six feet of social distancing. Exemptions include persons who cannot wear a face covering due to conditions that would cause trouble breathing, while eating and drinking, children under the age of 6. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200930 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf

When social distancing is not possible, all indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals statewide, and 50 outside. When social distancing is possible, all indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 20 individuals statewide, and 100 outside. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms.

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote)  all businesses, government offices, or other persons responsible for indoor spaces open to the public shall require and take reasonable measures to ensure that all employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, or other members of the public wear a face covering that covers their mouth and nose at all times while entering or remaining in any indoor spaces open to the public (quote). For all outdoor gatherings of 50 or more people, individuals are required to wear face coverings when it is not possible to maintain at least 6 ft of physical distance. Exemptions for children under 5, for individuals for whom wearing a mask is not medically possible, during exercise, etc. Technically only applies to counties with 4 or more confirmed active cases of COVID-19 (stongly encourages counties with 3 or fewer confirmed active cases to wear masks), but these locations are not clearly listed - subsequently, treating this as a statewide mandate. Coding as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as its requirements for outdoor settings are very limited.

Under the 19 regional directed health measures, gathering restrictions of 10 or more continue to at least 20200531. Religious services, including weddings or funerals are allowed but must maintain social distancing (6 ft apart) among parties of individuals. Easing began on 20200601, when 17 out of 19 regional health districts moved to the next phase http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/COVID-19-Outline-of-Changes-to-Upcoming-DHMs-Phase-II.pdf

Gathering restrictions to 25 people or 25 percent of applicable occupancy (whichever is greater) in 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County). Also exempts religious services. Began easing for 17 out of 19 health regions on 20200622 but the remaining two regions went to this gathering restriction, extending to 20200801 https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month.

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Every individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, and individuals who reside or resided with an individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, shall home-quarantine (quote) Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx Omitted from new set of directed health measures, now state recommendations are the policy: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Traveler-Recommendations.aspx

For 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County) that move to Phase 3, gathering restriction eased to 50 pct for an indoor facility occupancy, or 75 pct of outdoor facility occpancy. No gathering more than 10,000 people

PolicyCodingNotes: Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 50 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 50 people. Still requires physical distancing (i.e., 6 ft distancing). If less than 10 people, face masks are not required (recommended). These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.
LastUpdatedNotes: Edited OutGathLimReligious  and PolicyCodingNotes since limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings

PolicyCodingNotes: Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 100 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 100 people. Gathering restriction for outdoor gatherings is 250 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Quarantine advisory of 14 days for all individuals traveling from states with significant community spread of COVID-19, as operationalized by a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents or a 10 pct or higher positivity rate over a 7-day rolling average. While New York and Connecticut issued formal EOs for the quarantine, New Jersey never had a formal issuance - currently coding as an advisory. Initial list of states are: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah and Washington. By 20200630, list is 16 states. Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah. Washington state is no longer on the list https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey. By 20200707 list is 19 states: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey  On 20200714, added Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, Wisconsin: https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey On 20200721 the list includes 31 states, expands to include Alaska, Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Virginia and Washington. Expands mask requirement, requiring all customers to wears or cloth face coverings in all retail establishments, all of which may now re-open to the public (indoor and outdoor), restaurants (which are re-opened for indoor services on 20200702, already open for outdoor), and recreational and entertainment businesses when in the indoor portions of premises or distancing is not possible (such venues are health clubs, gyms, movie theaters). Coded as Mandate2 as this mandate now applies to broader set of indoor settings, inclusive of transportation services.
Limits outdoor gathering restrictions to no more than 500 people may gather in one location, physical distancing rules are adhered to, etc. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Expands mask requirement, mandating that (quote) when it is not practicable for individuals in outdoor spaces to socially distance and keep a six-foot distance from others...all individuals shall wear face coverings (quote). Previous orders focused on indoor spaces or confined areas, or specified gatherings. Clearly details that individuals must wear face coverings in indoor settings that are accessible to members of the public (e.g., retail, recreational and entertainment businsesses), government buildings open to the public, and mass transit buses, trains, and stations. Coded as a Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings broadly.

Expands indoor gathering restrictions to no more than 25 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. This does not apply to indoor religious gatherings, which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 100 people. Extends gathering restriction of up to 250 people outdoors. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Eases indoor gathering restrictions for religious indoor gatherings which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 150 people. Any other indoor meeting shall not exceed exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings. All attendees at an indoor gathering must wear face coverings at all times.

Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as the order approaches the mandate by listing out applicable settings rather than a more sweeping policy across indoor and outdoor settings. Wearing of masks or cloth face coverings is also recommended for customers/clients in various sectors under ND Smart Restart. It is likely that this recommendation was also under the original version of ND Smart Restart (announced on 20200429), but pdf documentation is not longer findable.

PolicyCodingNotes: Mandates face coverings in any indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors and unable to maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft, and waiting for riding public transportation, taxi, ride sharing. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor settings, as well as outdoor settings where social distancing is not possible. This is applicable to all counties that are designated as a Red Alert Level 3 Public Health Emergency or a Purple Alert Level 4 Public Health Emergency. As of 20200707: Butler County, Cuyahoga County, Franklin County, Hamilton County, Huron County, Montgomery County, Trumbull County. On 20200709, Huron is downgraded to Level 2: https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-07092020 On 20200710, more counties added, bringing the list to: Clermont, Fairfield, Lorain, Pickaway, Summit, Wood, Butler, Cuyahoga, Franklin, Hamilton, Montgomery, Trumbull. As of 20200716, Trumball is downgraded to Level 2 and in effect on 20200717, these additional counties are added: Athens, Allen, Delaware, Licking, Lucas, Richland, Scioto, Union. https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-0716-2020
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes to reflect changes in county alert levels

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals entering Ohio after travel in the following states are advised to self-quarantine for 14 days upon arrival: Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Mississippi, Nevada, South Carolina, and Texas.

Statewide mask mandate is issued and in effect at 6 pm on 20200723, requiring all individuals in Ohio to wear facial coverings in public at all times when at an indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors (but unable to maintain six-foot social distance from people who are not household members), waiting for, riding, driving, or operating public transportation, such as a taxi, a car service, or a private car used for ride-sharing. Exemptions are for individuals under the age of 10 years old, with a medical conditions or disability, etc. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal PHO was signed on 20200723, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722).
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicySource with formal PHO, updated DateIssued to 20200723

Easing began on 20200605 when counties could move to Phase 2: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-27.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Phase Two counties may have gatherings up to 50 in indoor spaces and 100 on outdoor spaces, conditional on following distancing requirements. For June 5, 14 counties went to Phase 2: Benton, Curry, Douglas, Grant, Jackson, Klamath, Lake, Lane, Linn, Morrow, Union, Wallowa, Wasco, Wheeler. For June 6, 14 more counties - Baker, Deschuetes, Clatsop, Columbia, Coos, Crook, Gilliam, Harney, Jefferson, Josephine, Malheur, Sherman, Umatilla, Yamhill - were added. For June 8, Tillamook moved to phase two, bringing the total to 29 of 36 counties in Phase Two.

PolicyCodingNotes: Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when at a place of business (sectors listed in the order), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Applies to the following counties: Clackamas, Hood River, Lincoln, Marion, Multnomah, Polk, and Washington (mixture of Phase One and Phase Two counties). Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.

Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering indoors for all counties, expanding the previous order that was only applicable to a subset of counties. Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.
Limits all indoor gatherings to no more than 10 statewide. This expanded restriction does not apply to business operations or churches at present.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands requirement to wear face coverings in outdoor public spaces when 6 ft of distance cannot be maintained, and continues previous order (i.e., public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when in indoor public spaces), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Coding to Mandate3 as it applies to broadly across indoor and outdoor settings. Starting 20200724, mandate is somewhat strengthened, applying to individuals 5 years and older: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37003

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein all indoor and outdoor social gatherings are limited to 10 people while civic, cultural, and faith-based gatherings are limited to 25. Eased on 20200821 with Umatilla going back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein (quote) all individuals should minimize all non-essential travel and stay at their home or place of residence as much as possible (quote). Initial gathering restriction activated with stay-at-home order for Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County. PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All individuals residing in Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County are ordered to stay at home except as needed to access, support, or provide life sustaining business, emergency, or government service (quote). Initial expiry date was 20200406. From 20200323 to 20200331, counties are steadily added to the stay-at-home order, and the order is extended to 20200430: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/20200331-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf

Expands gathering restriction to being statewide. Takes effect 8 pm on 20200401 until 20200430. Extended to 20200508: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200420-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf

Takes effect 8pm on 20200401. Exceptions include activities to access, support, or provide life-sustaining business, emergency, or government services, including child care for employees of life-sustaining businesses. This Order supersedes all previous Orders directing  (quote) Individuals to Stay at Home (quote) On 20200420, extended to 20200508: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200420-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf  24 counties moved to yellow phase, easing StayAtHome starting 20200508 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-sec-of-health-take-actions-on-stay-at-home-orders-issue-yellow-phase-orders/
Recommends that all Pennsylvanians wear a mask any time they leave their homes for life-sustaining reasons

Requires all customers to wear masks while on business premises and deny entry to individuals not wearing masks. However, individuals who cannot wear a mask due to a medical condition or are under 2 years old, per CDC guidance, may enter the premises and are not required to provide documentation of such medical condition. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to all essential retail in operation.

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands public mask mandate, requiring individuals to wear face coverings if they are outdoors and unable to maintain distance of six ft from others, in any indoor location, waiting for or riding on public transportation, taxi, ride share and like vehicles, etc. Provides some exemptions (i.e., medical/disability, under the age of 2 years). Coded as Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks across outdoors and indoors settings.

(quote) If you have traveled, or plan to travel, to an area where there are high amounts of COVID-19 cases, it is recommended that you stay at home for 14 days upon return to Pennsylvania. PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All indoor and outdoor social gatherings of more than fifteen (15) people in any public or private space are prohibited. (quote) Includes exceptions for receptions for weddings (50 indoor and 100 outdoor under strict distancing guidelines). Indoor gatherings at religious institutions can have 125 max. (quote) religious and faithbased organizations may conduct indoor in-person activities up to 66 pct percent of worship space capacity, subject to a cap of one hundred and twenty-five (125) people and to the Phase III guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations (quote). Outdoor religious events can have 250, but distancing and masking must be in effect. All houses of worship must develop a COVID control plan.

PolicyCodingNotes: Announcement from gov, not EO: (quote) I urge every school district in Tennessee to close as soon as practically possible, with all schools expected to close by Friday, March 20, 2020 at the latest. Schools should remain closed through March 31, 2020 to further mitigate the spread of this infectious disease and we will issue further guidance prior to March 31. (quote) On 20200325 governor continues to urge public school closures, but still no apparent issuance of a mandate. Confirmed by state education site: https://www.tn.gov/education/health-and-safety/update-on-coronavirus.html. Governor on 20200415 (quote) called on (quote) all schools to remain closed through the end of the school year, but continued to be a recommendation https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/covid-19-daily-bulletin/2020/4/15/covid-19-bulletin--9---april-15--2020.html. Announcement on July 28 indicates that governor encourages in-person instruction, thus ending recommendation to keep schools closed. All decisions about schools now made at district and individual level.

PolicyCodingNotes: All gathering restrictions now advisory language. (quote) Except as provided in this executive order, people should not be in groups larger than ten and should maintain six feet of social distancing from those not in their group. People over the age of 65 are strongly encouraged to stay at home as much as possible (quote)

(quote) for any outdoor gathering in excess of 100 people...the gathering is prohibited (quote). Allows for mayor of the city or county judge to approve of the gathering as long it is not inconsistent with other portions of the EO
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) every person in Texas shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial entity or other building or space open to public, or when in a outdoor public space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing (quote). Lists exemptions (e.g., person younger than 10, persons with medical conditions or disabilities that would prevent wearing a face covering). Technically does not apply to any county that has met some minimum of COVID-19 cases and that a county judge as permitted opt-out per the TDEM form. Treating as a statewide mandate since these counties are not detailed. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Exemption for religious gatherings.

(quote) for any outdoor gathering in excess of 10 people...the gathering is prohibited (quote). Allows for mayor of the city or county judge to approve of the gathering as long it is not inconsistent with other portions of EO-28
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

Vermonters shall wear masks or cloth facial gatherings over their nose and mouth any time they are in public spaces, indoors or outdoors, where they come in contact with others from outside their households, especially in congregate settings, and where it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 6 ft. Exemptions are for children under the age of 2 years old, individuals with medical or developmental conditions that make wearing a facial covering not possible, during strenuous exercise or activity. In effect 20200801. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200916 https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%203%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20.pdf Extended to 20201016 https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%205%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20_0.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: All individuals in Virginia shall remain at their place of residence. Ended on 20200605 by allowing EO-55 to expire then https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/eo/EO-65-Phase-Two.pdf

All public and private in-person gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited. As of 12 am on 20200515, individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items. This applied to Virginia excluding Northern Virginia Region and City of Richmond and County of Accomack, which still had gathering restrictions of 10 across settings beyond 20200515 after they were moved back to Phase Zero https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Requirement for all patrons 10 years and older to wear face coverings while inside public buildings and businesses. Explicitly lists personal care services, brick and mortal retail (essential and non-essential businesses), food and beverage establishments, entertainment and recreation businesses (also required in outdoor settings for these businesses if distancing cannot be maintained), shared transportation, and any indoor place shared by groups of people in close proximity to each other outside of personal residences. Coded as Mandate2 as it applies widely across indoor spaces.

All Virginia locations are now at Phase 1 for gatherings, such that gatherings of 10 or more are still prohibited, but with the exception that individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items.

Eases gathering restrictions to no more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc

Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased restrictions for gatherings. No more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: entertainment and recreational facilities, as well as personal care services like barbershops and hair salons, and retail stores unless they comply with public health recommendations and social distancing. Also (quote) public venues where people congregate for entertainment (quote). Eases restriction for counties that moved to Phase 2 (as of 20200518): Asotin, Columbia, Garfield, Lincoln, Ferry, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum, and Whitman. Their eligibility may have occurred prior to 20200518, additional documentation and confirmation is in-progress. Exact dates may change in the future. Extended to 20200807: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.6%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery   Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery Effective 20200730, all indoor fitness centers and like venues are limited to 5 people for Phase 2 counties, and up to 25 pct occupancy in Phase 3 counties. For Phase 3 counties, indoor movie theaters are also reduced to 25 pct occupancy, and indoor entertainment centers like mini golf, bowling alleys, arcades, card rooms are prohibited from re-opening https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-rollbacks-to-some-activities-to-slow-covid-19-exposure-19003e510127

Limited operations required (onsite consumption banned): restaurants, coffee shops, any social club, etc. Initial expiry is through midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401. Eases restrictions on in-person dine-in services for Phase 2 counties: Asotin, Columbia, Garfield, Lincoln, Ferry, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum, and Whitman (list of counties with eased restrictions as of 20200518): https://coronavirus.wa.gov/what-you-need-know/covid-19-county-variance-application-process  Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery Starting 20200730, reduced capacity limits for phase 3 counties for indoor services, prohibits sales of alcohol after 10 pm, limits indoor dining tables to individuals of the same household: https://medium.com/wagovernor/inslee-announces-rollbacks-to-some-activities-to-slow-covid-19-exposure-19003e510127

(quote) All people in Washington state shall immediately cease participating in all public and private gatherings and multi-preson activities for social, spiritual and recreational purposes, regardles of the number people of involved (quote). Began easing on 20200601 with Phase 2 locations being able to have gatherings of 5 or more https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf

State-wide immediate stay-at-home, effective immediately: https://mynorthwest.com/1782819/inslee-washington-stay-at-home-order/ Easing began with transition to Safe Start WA, no longer mandating statewide stay-at-home orders for all populations (high risk in Phase 1 counties) https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf Fully ended mandate on 20200703 as all populations are no longer mandate https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1
